item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

I kind of agree with Niall, I really can’t understand why people look down on so many jobs that provide basic, almost every-day needs. If everyone in the world had a super fancy job, there would be no roads, construction, and a general lack of manual labor.

Read full topic

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Nurture doesn’t shape the entire character, but it plays a very important role. Of course you can’t judge someone by his or her job, but generally speaking it says a bit about their character, because character is one of the things that decides what job you end up doing. An introvert person usually doesn’t end up as a car salesman.

Read full topic

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

eh. sometimes how you’re raised doesn’t change who you are. i was raised by people who wanted me to be super successful and pushed me to make it happen, ended up dropping out of one college & getting kicked out of another. you can’t blame all of a persons character on how they were raised, some of it is just how it is and some of it is the persons individual responsibility

edit: and i know a happy plumber

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Niall:

the only problem is paved roads and working plumbing are an absolute necessity and in the case of the latter a human right, I don’t quite see why you appear to be looking down at those jobs

I’m not looking down at those jobs. But you can’t deny that those jobs aren’t what you wish for for your child. Besides, most people aren’t really satisfied with those jobs.

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Sure, the way you were brought up plays a major role in how you raise your own children. But I assume you can break that circle, and do it differently. For instance, my parents’ generation was still raised in a time when you could smack your child. Yet now it’s frowned upon by almost everyone, only a small part of parents still do.

I know this is a generalization, but here in the Netherlands you do see a lot of uneducated and low-income people use violence against their children. I know you don’t see education as something that makes you superior, Mopman. I agree, but being educated usually is a result of being raised differently (and I daresay a bit better). Dropouts, or people who don’t even try, usually don’t succeed at much else either. They prefer short term satisfaction over long term, and end up paving the road or fixing my sink. They have the same potential as those who do succeed, but they lack the drive to achieve.

(I say again, I’m generalizing here. There are exceptions, but on average I think I’m close to being right :P)

Read full topic

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @zuppers zuppers
item.description:
@zuppers wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:147, topic:420280”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=522832.msg3983000#msg3983000 date=1335514890]
I’m fairly certain everyone here was given a boiled egg baby as a kid at school.
[/quote]
We had to take care of an ‘egg baby’ for an entire week, and it was a substantial part of our grade. Mine had a slight crack in it that I repaired with super-glue and went over with white-out to give it that egg color again, the teacher never noticed, and I got a good grade.

Maybe that’s why I’m a good parent now… :P[/quote]Are you the parent of Michael Jackson, it sure would explain alot.

Read full topic

We had to take care of an ‘egg baby’ for an entire week, and it was a substantial part of our grade. Mine had a slight crack in it that I repaired with super-glue and went over with white-out to give it that egg color again, the teacher never noticed, and I got a good grade.

Maybe that’s why I’m a good parent now…

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:143, topic:420280”]i have no idea waht a boiled egg baby is it sounds like something bad mothers do like shaken baby syndrome

i assume you had to look after an egg as if it was a kid or something?[/quote]

Yeah, it was only for a day at school. Was pretty funny because we all just broke them at first break time iirc so I guess it wasn’t an excellent teaching exercise. ;D

However it came accompanied with a lesson on “How to be parent”, not that I really remember any of it but I’m fairly sure most people should have experienced something like this at school, it seems rather important.

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Heh so apparently when you knock a girl up you automatically become an expert on parenting because you are one?

You can have kids once you’re sexually mature, and historically that was what happened. It’s only in the last 30 years that house prices and inflation skyrocketed making parenting a much more expensive task and less feasbile before ~30.

Read full topic

item.title: Fuck everything about this
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Stork:

itt: young people talking about parenting.

itt: people without children of their own talking about parenting

Stork:

the video showed a girl getting slapped with a belt. Not beaten, just slapped. She’ll be a little sore for a bit, but in a few days it will all be forgotten, and she sure as shit won’t do whatever thing she did to warrant the punishment.

if you look at the video description:

The judge's wife was emotionally abused herself and was severely manipulated into assisting the beating and should not be blamed for any content in this video. The judge's wife has since left the marriage [b]due to the abuse, which continues to this day[/b], and has sincerely apologized and repented for her part and for allowing such a thing, long before this video was even revealed to exist.

whether or not you want to call it abuse or being “slapped” with a belt you have to draw the line somewhere, the wife and daughter obviously feel it was abuse (assuming the video description is accurate) and it wasn’t a one off experience

how about this, it isn’t necessarily the kid not wanting to accept the punishment, it’s more to do with the kid not wanting to be hit/slapped/lightly touched like a feather repeatedly several times with a belt, where such a punishment anywhere else in western society is against the law

Read full topic
